This is somehow one of the best and worst game engines.

The good: 
- Everything is templated out for you. There are default maps, characters, events, etc that you can use to help you learn.
- You don't need to learn how to code at all - the built-in functions can be used to easily make a basic game.
- If you do code manually, it uses Javascript, a well-understood language that's been around for ages.
- Tons of resources online to do almost anything you want.

The bad:
- If you do want to be a smarty-pants and manually code, the box where you enter your code is like 320x240 and can't be expanded, and is limited to 12 lines. It is basically a text box with no IDE functions. That is horrible.
- In fact, none of the editor's windows can be resized, and they were designed around 720p screens. If you have a higher resolution than that, everything will be tiny and there's nothing you can do about it.
- Almost all documentation of script calls for functions is in Japanese.
- Want to write a method or an object? Too bad - on top of having no space to do it, these are stripped and discarded when the game is saved/loaded. This is one of the worst decisions I've seen from a game engine, ever. MZ has the same problem as far as I can tell.
- There are no protections for your game. If someone wants to steal your code, assets, etc, it will take less than 5 minutes. You can """"encrypt"""" your image/audio files when deploying, but there are tools online to decrypt them easily.

TL;DR - if you're a normal user that knows nothing about code and doesn't want to do anything interesting, this is the way to go. If you want to level up your game, grow up and use Godot, Unity, Unreal, anything else. It's gonna be hard, but it'll take you much further.

I've tried a few of the RPG Maker engines and MV is by far the worst for stability and crashes if you dont adhere to its limitations. On the plus side the RTP is pretty generous and decent enough to not need anything else for a beginner, but previous iterations of the engine had better music, sprites and aesthetic imo.

People say that there is much more plugin support and while that is true MZ has a good amount of them built into it. I'd pick up MZ over MV its just better supported and more stable which matters a lot more than you initially think.

- If you do code manually, it uses Javascript, a well-understood language that's been around for ages.
- Tons of resources online to do almost anything you want.

The bad:
- If you do want to be a smarty-pants and manually code, the box where you enter your code is like 320x240 and can't be expanded, and is limited to 12 lines. It is basically a text box with no IDE functions. That is horrible.
- In fact, none of the editor's windows can be resized, and they were designed around 720p screens. If you have a higher resolution than that, everything will be tiny and there's nothing you can do about it.
- Almost all documentation of script calls for functions is in Japanese.
- Want to write a method or an object? Too bad - on top of having no space to do it, these are stripped and discarded when the game is saved/loaded. This is one of the worst decisions I've seen from a game engine, ever. MZ has the same problem as far as I can tell.
- There are no protections for your game. If someone wants to steal your code, assets, etc, it will take less than 5 minutes. You can """"encrypt"""" your image/audio files when deploying, but there are tools online to decrypt them easily.

TL;DR - if you're a normal user that knows nothing about code and doesn't want to do anything interesting, this is the way to go. If you want to level up your game, grow up and use Godot, Unity, Unreal, anything else. It's gonna be hard, but it'll take you much further.

I recently switched PCs and MV just doesn't load on the new PC. The splash screen happens and then nothing. I've spent thousands of hours on this project between writing, creating artwork, and building the game. And now I can't finish it because it just doesn't open. I tried changing the project to MZ, but the plugins the game relies on don't work with MZ. So when I deploy the game it gives an error.

So be warned. If you switch to a new PC, the program may just not work and you could end up losing everything. You're better off finding a different program to use.

Late to the reviews but RPG Maker is just slop at this point. Do not recommend their brand as a whole. From dismissive/toxic staff on their forums, to releasing game assets and music that will likely land you in a copyright lawsuit, it's just not the way to go (people were changing a few chords to a song and they didn't review it before releasing it to their store). And we can't forget that they charge a 100$ pricetag for the bare minimum of updates between their software releases!

I had fun learning and creating silly things, but the software in general is extremely limited and all it will ever be good for are gimmicks that all look the same. For a software that was supposed to be beginner friendly, I sure had to go out my way to find the people that are willing to teach you how these things work in greater detail. When I tried contacting the forums in the early 2000's I was immediately hit with a 'you shouldn't be making a thread about this because the question has already been asked', and yet none of the staff could provide me with a link to a thread with the relevant tutorial to prove it.

A very unwelcoming and socially stunted community in general.
